description:
I was in the area and wanted a coffee and stumbled upon this place. The Richfield is a small little coffee shop in the Inner Richmond district. There are a few tables inside and outside, and they offer free WiFi. There is a nice vibe here, I saw a couple people chilling and some doing work! 

I looked at the menu and ordered the Cold Brew. The Cold Brew was good, smooth and not too bitter. It came with coffee ice cubes, a very nice touch to keep the ice from diluting the drink.

I came on a weekday afternoon and found street parking fairly easily. The staff was nice and friendly. Convenient neighborhood coffee shop to visit if you're ever in the area!
author: Michael L.

description:
What a cute little coffee shop! It's pretty easy to miss as it's in a funny triangle at California and 5th. This is what good coffee should taste like.

After living in Australia for a number of years I'm always on the lookout for a real Aussie style flat white and this did not disappoint. Exactly the right size and the espresso was smooth and perfect. I was only visiting SFO for a couple of days and made sure to come back 2 mornings in a row to get my FW. I found them on Yelp and they definitely earn the great reviews.
author: Mel A.

description:
Love this place! Coffee is great and service is consistently friendly. Place is tiny, but that doesn't mean there's no atmosphere. It's casual here and I love the green walls. Parking is not easy if you're not in the neighborhood already. Came here recently on a Saturday morning and there were families, groups, individuals, everyone in the neighborhood basically coming over to Richfield. I'm assuming you will be next! 

I ordered a latte and banana bread. Everything came out to $8 total. Delicious everything!
author: Debby N.

description:
Brekkie Sandwich - lives up to the hype.  Simple ingredients, but delicious.

Cold Brew - they use ice cubes made with coffee to keep the brew from tasting watered down as you savor every sip.  So novel and simple that not even the big coffee chains do it.  Props to The Richfield on that.

Seating - they promptly opened at 7:30 and I got one of the few seats inside.  Enjoyed a good book while eating and drinking.  Small interior, but very relaxing.

Will try their Avocado Toast and a hot brew next time...
author: Mario P.

description:
Have you even gone to a coffee shop and asked "May I get a cup of coffee" and received the snooty response "well, this IS a coffee shop."?  I have a couple of times over the years and don't really appreciate the sarcasm, particularly when I still haven't had my morning cup.  And while I haven't been given this response at The Richfield, I feel like they want to say that.  If you ask for a cappuccino or latte with non-fat milk (as my SO often does) you are at the very least told that they don't have non-fat, but might be told the additional detail that non-fat milk doesn't make quite a proper type of foam.  

Don't get me wrong, we like the Richfield food and coffee and enjoy the boxing theme and old copies of The Ring magazine to browse.  And the location is sort of cool - what for years was a wedge shaped island off of California is now a small 2 story building with The Richfield in the lower floor.

The breakfast items are tasty and well made, the coffee drinks are good (though I have a couple other preferences in SF).  So we stop in when we are in the area and in need of a bite or coffee.  Prices are a touch high, but not out of line.  They don't seem big on substitutions, and if you want almond milk be prepared to fork over another $0.75 for your drink.  And ask for Earl Grey tea (the preference of my SO) and they may look down on you as being too pedestrian (which is funny because there is no parking in the area so only pedestrians can get there).

It just seems that they have a bit of an attitude - maybe it's the boxing décor that brings it out in them.  Hopefully it won't turn people off from going there - though there is a bit of competition in the area with Beanstalk, Blue Danube, and Cumaica all within a block or three.  I expect a bit of attitude in the Marina or SOMA, but not in Inner Richmond.

So 5 stars for the food and boxing theme, 4 for the location and coffee, 3 for the limited tea selection and perceived attitude.  A 4 star review.
author: Jeff H.

description: Very popular coffee shop with locals. Good food, nice people, cool vibe and serious baristas.  These guys moved into this space a few years ago and made themselves part of the neighborhood. This is the 2nd location of Snowbird coffee.  And now they have opened a 3rd.  Come here more than once and you'll see the same people working here. Very quickly they get to know you and offer great service.  If you're a high quality coffee fan and you haven't tried this place you must soon. If you have already then you're probably a regular!
author: Kelly P.

description:
I love this tiny coffee shop in the median of an intersection. It's a cute neighborhood spot to pop in for a coffee or a snack.

I just get whatever latte or ice coffee drink that I'm feeling that day, and (if I'm lucky), snag a seat at one of the 3 tiny, 2-3 person tables they have. When the weather is nice, sometimes there are 2, 2-seater tables outside.They also have a little counter that I've seen some people stand at to do work. I personally don't find the environment conducive to working, but it's fun to people watch and read a little on a slow day. I also tend to prefer small cozy coffee shops to large ones.

The service is friendly, the drinks are pretty average (though they have a few interesting selections and a large variety of tea), and the food is pretty unique. I think the breakfast sandwich is popular (but not a stunner, according to my NYC-breakfast-sandwhich-loving friend). I have also tried the sesame ricotta toast topped with strawberries, coconut flakes, and honey. It's an interesting combination, and I enjoyed it, but I'm not sure if it completely worked. Maybe in strawberry season, when the strawberries are a little more naturally sweet, it would make sense.

Almond milk is extra and they will remind you like Chipotle employees remind you that guac is extra.
author: Alice L.

description: Great coffee and food! The shop is a tad small but very cute! Great customer service!
author: Melita V.

description:
Great for a quick brunch or coffee on the go! My beau and I grabbed two brekkie sandwiches and a couple of coffees to-go, but ended up eating outside when a table opened up. 

If you're looking to meet with a friend for a chat, or just enjoy the Sunday paper and have a nice morning to yourself, The Richfield definitely works for both.
author: Siobhan F.

description: Finally--a good coffee spot in the neighborhood! The food is a little on the pricey side, but it's what you'd expect for San Francisco. I had a latte and it was excellent. It's a small place, so it wouldn't be a great location to hang around for a long time or hole up for a work session. The Richfield is definitely my new go-to spot for Sunday morning coffee on my way to/from the farmers market.
author: Marissa V.

description: Cute coffee corner. Coffee, avocado bread, matcha latte and service is great. Love coming by here for a snack and picker upper before doing my nails at Polish. It's only a block away ...score!
author: Christy V.

description:
The Richfield is by far the cutest, hippest, and (still) the best place to get coffee in the Inner Richmond, even though the drip coffee has admittedly gone down a bit in quality since it became my regular spot six months ago. I grab coffee from them 2-3 times a week, and the staff is always excellent to me, even when the line is long and their small kitchen is humming.

Why four stars? Mondays and pastries, basically. It's frustrating to hike my butt over only to realize they are closed, and then hike my butt back to Blue Danube. I've more or less got it committed to memory now, but I still like Richfield better; I want to go there on Mondays too. As for the pasties? They are almost always out by the time I get in. These must be the fanciest, most in-demand pastries ever, because whenever I come knocking for some flaky goodness, I always leave empty handed. They have cooked food, but I'm usually not looking for that kind of commitment, ya know?
author: Chris C.

description:
What a quaint little spot! Emphasis on little. Although a bit cramped, I love the ambiance of this place. It was a little unexpected, but this place commemorates (fictional/non-fictional) boxing's all-time greatest. Loved the quote painted on the wall and the retro boxing gloves hanging by the cashier. 

Ok, onto the coffee.. I ordered a latte with almond milk and my boyfriend got a simple iced coffee. Both came out to $9 even. Typical hipster coffee price. Not mad about it all because the quality of their coffee is so worth it! I'm a stickler for strong coffee and I need it in a precise way. I took one sip into my heart-shaped latte and fell in love. It was rich, creamy, velvety, and kicked me with caffeine. Just the way I like it! I happily sipped my cup outside, on a rare sunny day. 

Side note: the cashier was a bit snooty and kept conversation short. It's cool. Their exceptional quality in coffee makes up for it. I'll be here more often to try everything.
author: Rachelle Y.

description:
Even if it was just a little neighborhood coffee spot with nothing more than their amazing beverage selection and some generic muffins, the charming ambiance, tasty coffee, and friendly service would still probably earn it five stars in my book. But what takes The Richfield above and beyond is their unique and delicious food menu. I was obsessed with the black sesame ricotta toast topped with fresh strawberries and coconut. I've never seen this combo anywhere else but as soon as I spotted it on the menu it was a where-have-you-been-all-my-life type of moment! 

Though it's teeny with just a few small tables, it's a great addition to this neighborhood and I'm jealous of people who live in the area and can stop by on the regular. I'll definitely be back on my next trip to SF!
author: Christina P.

description: The employees are super sweet. They have this bomb chia pudding just ask for some honey to put on top . The place is small & intimate. They have a short menu of breakfast food but it's more like a light bite to go. Definitely coming back :)
author: Erica R.

description: The cutest little coffee shop next to a busy street. A breezy walk from work is definitely a plus. Delicious coffee and matcha latte!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I was at another place debating getting a $10 acai bowl and then realized that wasn't what I was feeling at all. Luckily the Richfield was nearby, so I just walked down the street to it. It's in a weird location right in the middle of where California and Cornwall start to meet, but I like that it's a small location with seats both inside and outside. The menu is pretty simple, but they do have coffee specials.

This time around I went for a latte and their black sesame ricotta toast. The cost all together was about the same as what I would have paid for with that original acai bowl! The black sesame toast comes out with strawberries and toasted coconut on top. I wasn't expecting that, but I really liked the combination. You get a good amount of ricotta, but I wish the black sesame flavor had been stronger. Without it, you're really just eating a gray cheese, even with those delicious toppings!
author: Grace C.

description:
3 stars because very few people like ice chunks in their ice cream.

Got the affogato with the caramel ice cream and it had lots of ice crystals in it. Maybe I'm the only one ordering ice cream so the ice cream is old and cold and frozen over like Hell.

The coffee shot on top was okay. A little bitter but overall not worth the $5 I paid.

$4.50 plus 50¢ tip.

Their coffee is on the strong side which isn't my particular taste. I'm more of a medium flavored coffee drinker. 

So overall 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description:
Super cute coffee place with a very friendly staff. We were in the area and came across the cafe, in a great area around a lot of food. 

The drinks are good. We tried a cappuccino and matcha latte which were both delicious. 

Would definitely come back!
author: Jhankhana J.

description:
I dig this wee cafe. It's cosy yet there's some room to hang. One finds a few 2-top tables inside, and more than a few out. Plus there's a 'Steh-Cafe' type counter running along the window facing California Street. It's good for a lean.

Their cold brew is fairly tasty, and they top it off with cold brew coffee ice cubes. One can slowly sip the drink and not have it become watered-down. -nice touch. 

Both coffee and baked goods are locally procured: goodies from Devil's Teeth in the Outer Sunset & beans (12 oz  bags sold as well) from Snowbird in the Inner Sunset.

In addition to beverages, their menu includes very modest brunch-type food offerings. I can't comment on them because I come strictly for the coffee drinks and baked nibbles. Expect fancy toast in a few different permutations.

**tidy loo
**third-wave coffee
**friendly service
**short hours throughout the week: Tues-Fri open 'til 3pm; Sat-Sun: open 'til 4pm
author: Bea B.

description:
This place is awesome--I would chill here all the time if I lived in the area. It's a small spot at an intersection in the Inner Richmond, perfect for grabbing a cup on the go or for posting up for a chat with friends/getting some work done/whatever your steez happens to be. There are a couple tables inside and a few more outside, wrapped around the building. We grabbed a couple Coffees and Brekkie Sandwiches and sat outside, watching the cars and pedestrians pass by. We would've stayed even longer but had to hurry to a nearby event. 

The Brekkie Sandwiches stole our hearts. Two slices of Hawaiian Bread packed with the perfect amount of Egg, Cheese, and Bacon, and a slightly sweet Sauce to elevate all the flavors. The Choop (gooey cheese that poops out the back of a sandwich) was already oozing out before I even took a bite, and it was glorious. 

Five stars for location, decor, service, and quality. Can't wait to visit again when we're in the area.
author: Jon S.

description:
Quaint little spot with a nice decor that smelled really good. Got the brekkie sandwich and a chai latte. 

Everything tastes pretty good but there were a few issues. My sandwich kinda got thrown together so for instance my cheese wasn't really melted. The chai latte was kinda weak. All in all, I'd probably give them another shot.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I had a "brekkie " sandwich that looked like white bread with dried out egg. My lips curled, my eyebrows rose and I prepared for disappointment. WRONG!

Holy moly. Chill place. Great coffee.
author: Mario T.

description: Nice, hip little place. Happy to find "Aussie" style lattes and flat whites on the menu. Cooked food can take a long time which is fine if you're not in a hurry during morning peak. A few cosy seats inside and some outside seating but seems to be more of a takeout coffee place.
author: Rozie W.

description:
So remind me again why I find myself in the Richmond at 8AM on a Saturday morning when I live way over in SoMa? Oh no, it wasn't the embarrassing aftermath of some drunken binge at Ireland's 32. As usual, I get my car serviced every few months at the Toyota dealer on Geary. Of course that means leaving my car for an hour and a half, and then what...wait in the room with all the other early-bird Asian owners of Toyotas. Instead of living down to my stereotype, I scrolled the Yelp app to see what was open, and lo and behold, that's how I stumbled onto this closet of a place just two blocks away off California.

There on the chalk wall is their humble slogan, "Never surrender if you want to be a contender", which made me think of Brando's classic line in "On the Waterfront": "I coulda been a contender, I coulda been somebody, instead of a bum, which is what I am." As I pondered that philosophy, I had to make the tough decision between their two breakfast items, the $6 Black Sesame Ricotta Toast with honey and granola, and the $7 Brekkie Sandwich, which offered a folded omelette, melted cheddar cheese, crispy bacon, and some house special sauce that they spread on two slices of King's Hawaiian toast.

No contest for me as the Brekkie did it for me (photo: http://bit.ly/2amtzco), and while it wasn't anything that extraordinary, I have to admit it was the thick slices of King's Hawaiian that really made this quite satisfying. The luxuriant $3.75 Cappuccino I ordered to go with it also did the trick (photo: http://bit.ly/2a3Lq5H), and it was honestly relaxing to have such a simple meal at a little cafe table. It's a popular spot as a growing number of people started to come in soon after me, and I soon felt guilt for taking up one of the three tables when young couples had to stand at the counter. Oh, who am I kidding? Millennials need to work on their posture anyway.

FOOD - 4 stars...it's the King's Hawaiian bread that makes the difference, seriously
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...nice little spot...very little
SERVICE - 4 stars...young and attentive, a unique combination these days
TOTAL - 4 stars...a nice brekkie for me
author: Ed U.

description:
I wanted to like this place, but something was just missing. 

Ordered:

Cold Brew - I must say I was pleasantly surprised when I saw the barista put in coffee ice cubes instead of the #basic water cubes im my cup prior to filling it with that black gold. I was excited to be given that extra ounce of caffiene without my cold brew being dilluted. It was only after a few sips I began to realize that the ice had given my coffee that freezer taste..that old ice taste. Ugh. I think they have a promising concept, but the execution of protecting the ice has to be worked out. 

Bacon & cheese muffin - It was ok. Wasn't given an option to heat it up, but maybe it would have tasted better then? It had a good amount of bacon bits, but didn't have much of a cheesy taste.

All in all it was ok. I wouldn't say there'd be anything to keep me going back.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Although this coffee shop is pretty small, I think it has a lot of character to it.

My friend and I were walking around and wanted to grab some coffee before our succulent crafting date and decided to stop by here. The place is pretty tiny, and honestly, I think we almost missed it as we were passing by, but I'm glad the bright blue tables caught my eye!!

I ordered a vanilla latte and thought it was pretty strong. I prefer my coffee to have somewhat of a stronger coffee taste, and I thought that they made it very very strong, so I just added a little sugar to my liking; however, the one thing that was missing for me was the vanilla portion! I felt like I just ordered a regular latte, so I was kind of disappointed.

Service here was ok. The person who rang me up seemed "meh" so I kept my interaction at a minimal. 

The place seriously reminds me of a very cute coffee shop in the middle of a city, but it's more on the quiet side in the area and isn't as busy. I literally can imagine myself sitting here just having a cute coffee date or reading a book on a Sunday morning. 

I see a lot of other people raving about their other coffees though, so next time I will give those a try.
author: Tricia N.

description:
The avocado  toast was amazing! Paired it with the matcha  great combo. 

The service was questionable... 
me: walk in 
Cashier: stares at me
Me: *waiting on the "hey what can I get you"
Cashier: continues to stare. 
Me: uhhh hi may I get a ... 
Cashier: your name? Okay sign here .

I'm like wtffff.. not going to judge. Maybe this is how things flow here. None of the stafff were smiling, shoooot. I'd be. Coffee and breakfast food all morning is heaven. 

Pricey but worth the food. Experience could been better. I'll be back maybe I'll get a what's up what can I get you next time.
author: Kent B.

description: I really wanted to love this place, but my brekkie sandwich was totally burnt. The service/friendly faces were also lacking.
author: Betty T.

description: Super cute neighborhood cafe! Good coffee, friendly staff, tasty brekkie sandwich - that bacon and eggs mmmmm! Not a whole lot of seating so not a camp out with your laptop kind of spot. But with the tables outside it's great to chill with a quick caffeine boost or a bite. Love it!
author: Nana L.

description: Really sweet (and hip!) neighborhood cafe with just the right amount of kitschy-ness. The folks working here are friendly, service timing felt appropriate (they have a tinnnnny kitchen!), and both items I ordered were delicious (avocado toast and matcha latte)! I feel like if this was in Hayes Valley or Pac Heights this place might have felt pretentious, but for where it's located, with the neighborhood it's servicing, it's delightful. There was a steady stream of customers while we were there, but it never felt packed. Chill vibe, great addition to the neighborhood - I'll definitely be back. (Tip: grab an outdoor table on the side of the building if the sun is out. Basking in the sun with a matcha latte is a hard combo to top)
author: Ashley H.

description:
Have seldom been to a coffee shop - especially in SF - where the baristas/cashiers greet you with a dismal look & make your entire stay less than pleasant. 

After grabbing a salad from nourish cafe, my bf and I came here to read & to chat. To my dismay, the service was simply lacking. We wanted to leave by what felt like a hostile environment, but when you need your coffee - you need your coffee. "They're probably just high schoolers," said my bf - but I know tons of high schoolers who are capable of giving out a cup of coffee with great service.

Etc:
- Seating: There's room for around 6 inside with 2 small tables outside. 
- A restroom is present inside. 

Was excited to come here after seeing it while walking by but definitely won't be returning. Better luck next time.
author: Rachel Y.

description: Not bad, good coffee and interesting looking food and pastry. If space is your thing or you're worried about scuffing your designer shoes, you better not pop in. This is a very claustrophobic room. Staff makes up for any issues.
author: Henry K.

description:
would come back mainly for the atmosphere. the coffee doesn't disappoint but doesnt drive me back.

cute cafe on a quaint street but between busy streets. some seating both inside and outside.
ordered a flat white (with whole milk) -- good but nothing notable

super friendly and prompt service
author: Jeanie N.

description:
Very cozy, quaint cafe (3 small tables inside; 2 outside). Overall very chill vibe and chill music. Fast, free Wi-Fi. No limit for credit card.

The coffee here is delicious! I took my double-shot Americano without any milk or sugar, and it was perfectly smooth and creamy. 

Since it's at the corner near a more residential area, parking is not too bad. Free street parking is available just a block down. 

Minus one star because they charge $0.75 extra for COLD almond milk! Typically, cafes charge extra for steamed almond milk or almond milk substitution in lattes, etc... but NOT for cold almond milk :( They also only carry whole milk and half&half (no skim, no soy).
author: Samantha C.

description: Cool small local cafe. Great coffee and Breakfast sandwich. Their late was really good. Just the right amount of sweetness I'm looking for in a late. Sandwich was really tasty and filling. It comes on a thicker style toasted bread, eggs, cheese, bacon and some type of marmalade or something. Really nice touch of sweetness. You can add avocado and other stuff, but honestly it's super filling as it is, so I'd just stick with the original. Cool vibe, but not a lot of seating (which I kinda prefer a smaller cafe anyways).
author: Renato S.

description: This place was so great. Loved the avocado toast, which was so unique because it had pickles in it! Very tasty. I also had hot earl gray tea... so delicious! Friendly staff, too.
author: Emily H.

description: This place has the best cappuccinos in the city, IMO. The foam has actually mixed with the coffee so you get that amazing flavor of coffee in the background while you are experiencing the foam texture. Which is what's supposed to happen, but rarely does. We also love their breakfast sandwiches, which are sweet and savory. It also has great outdoor seating in a quiet neighborhood.
author: Alexi V.

description: Small place with chill music. Had an almond milk cappuccino and the brekkie sandwich. Both were great. They have a small seating area outside as well.
author: Johannes M.

description: This is a great little coffee spot in the Inner Richmond.  It's a very small space with decent lattes and a few tables (both inside and out).  It's small, but nice ambiance and friendly staff.  Great place to grab a cup if you're in the area!
author: Rachel R.

description: When I first found this place in Yelp, I thought it would be in a busy area but it's in a small block. The weather of San Francisco made me crave for a latte so I decided to make a trip to the Richfield since I was around the area. I ordered a matcha latte. When I took a sip from the latte, it didn't seem sweetened but I'm okay with that because it was really good. I love matcha, sweetened or not.  The guy that took my order didn't asked if I wanted sweetened or not. I'm from New York so a lot of coffee shops ask me if I would like it sweeten or not. It didn't affect how I feel about this coffee shop anyways. I would definitely come back again when I visit San Francisco again and is around the Richmond area.
author: Lisa L.

description:
One of my favorite coffee shops in the city, (and I've been to over 50 in SF). What sets this apart? It sits on a neighborhoody street and the few tables inside make it a cozy atmosphere.

The flat white is excellent.  Not many places in the city offer one, and it tastes like the ones in New Zealand. (Starbucks offers a flat white, but isn't nearly as good). 

The Brekky sandwich (folded omelette, bacon and cheddar) was delicious! The housemade Hawaiian bread took it to the next level. 

Would definitely recommend coming here to have coffee with a friend or bring a book and settle in.
author: Kevin B.

description:
#tl;dr Deece, shows promise, but has some item availability x service kinks to smooth out.

Out of bacon = 30min wait for Breakfast Sando.
I bought one bc #nottrippin.
10ish mins later, I'm given a sandwich.
Without bacon; it was someone else's order.
Another 10 and "so sorry, we're out of bacon! it'll be a half hour".
#waitwhat isn't that why I started waiting 20mins ago?
Then nearly an hour in, sandwich achieved.
Nice texture but mostly flavorless, go figure.

Korean Fried Chicken was better & way faster.
Interesting ice cubes made of coffee.
Duck Hunt x Mike Tyson's Punch-Out!! vibe.
Hipster vs Yoga Parent clientele showdown.
author: Dan B.

description:
Welcome to the Inner Richmond!

The wait is finally over; the space that was once Ro Cafe, is now The Richfield.

From what I understood from the nice girl, Anna, is that this is the new sister cafe to Snowbird Coffee over on 9th and Irving. It's a boxing themed space with a dark forest green color scheme. They even have an old school locker that serves as a shelf for their Snowbird bean bags. It's very small though, so seating will probably be challenging. But in terms of a to-go spot, it'll be as good as any.

I have yet to try their food; but it all sounded delicious, judging by the descriptions on the menu.

This place has good quality/skillfully crafted coffee, which I'm sure the food will follow suit. I look forward to not having to walk all the way to Fifty Fifty anymore.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Pretty cool location. Small but cozy. 
Pastries from Devils teeth and coffee from snowbird roaster.
they have handcrafted drip coffees or the usual lattes and cappucino.  They also serve toasts and sandwiches.  didn't get to try them this time, but ill be back to this local spot.
author: Linda T.

description:
Fast, tasty well executed breakfast.  Cappuccino was perfectly brewed, with ribbons of foam through the deep rich coffee without the slightest hint of butter notes.   Let me be clear about this,... I think 95% of the cappuccinos out there are made by halfwits with no clue as to what coffee is. Richfield did it right!

Egg & bacon on med-thick crisp toast with a touch of maple syrup (maybe 1/2 teaspoon) for flavor was outstanding.  Although the toast was thick, it wasn't too dense, yet it held up extraordinarily well to the generous portion of perfectly cooked eggs and half crisp bacon. It was a pleasure to eat and didn't fall apart. Why doesn't everyone make a breakfast sandwich like this?

I also had a doughnut muffin. OK, I'm gonna be honest with you. It was a dance doughnut in the shape of a medium size muffin. If you were avoiding gluten, this isn't the thing for you. It had a modest amount of sugar sprinkled on top and was delicious. But, it was gluten Central. But, it's a damn doughnut, so what do you expect!  It delivers on what it is and is very filling. Recommend splitting one with someone.  Prices were very reasonable. 

Seven bucks for the sandwich. All told it was about 13 bucks including tax, before tip. Not too bad for a hearty breakfast done well in San Francisco.

Only issue is parking. But, if you live in San Francisco and drive everywhere you're an idiot. Find a parking space within a couple blocks and walk on in. It's worth the small tiny bit of effort. So stop bitching and moaning about the parking and get off your lazy arse and walk a few blocks.  You'll feel better about getting the doughnut muffin. :-)
author: Alex K.

description:
Thank god for The Richfield. My weekend mornings would be so much worse without you. Located on a concrete island, and with a small interior, I wouldn't exactly call this cafe a "destination". However, as neighborhood coffee shops go, The Richfield is as good as they get! It seems like most of the customers are regulars, and you'll always find a couple cute dogs tied up outside patiently waiting. It can get a little crowded, but I've never had trouble finding a table.

The lattes are amazing and probably my favorite in the city. They have a subtle nutty, roasted taste. The cold brew and regular coffee are great too. I've had the avo toast and the black ricotta sesame toast, and both are very tasty.

Honestly, these days you could throw a rock anywhere in SF and hit a place that has avocado toast and fancy coffee. It's harder to find a place with a perfect combination of good food, good coffee, good people, and good vibes. The Richfield doesn't disappoint.
author: Cat M.

description: Best triple flat white in the area. This place gets popular..... Really crowded around lunch time...I love their beans.
author: Koalie W.

description:
I had a yummy little matcha latte here on a sunday afternoon. It was so yummy. This cafe has a few interesting options on board that I look forward to going back and trying. I had to ask the girl behind the counter what each of the unknowns to me were. She was so kind and helpful.
This is a very small cafe with a limited, albeit yummy, food selection. I look forward to going back to try a different drink option and a chia pudding.
author: Michelle G.

description: Having driven passed this cafe for years, I finally decided to check it out this morning. Nice tables are set up outside the place on 5th Avenue. Fit for a coffee break or a light snack! Even though the place is very small, it does have it's perks. I ordered a Coffee Cake that I devoured in a minute! I'm definitely going back!
author: Julio B.

description:
I went to the Richfield yesterday around 2:27pm and there was a woman who seems like the owners' friend. She stood in front of the counter chatting with the people working there. I waited patiently for a while. Until she was done with her chatting, I went order my food. I only got told "Sorry. No orders for sandwiches after 2:30pm." I tried to tell them I was waiting there and they knew it; but I only got "Sorry. No." 

I was disappointed. This coffee shop used to be one of my favorite spots. I was traveling for half year and I wanted to go Richfield after the long trip. But they only care to chat with friends but not their services.
author: Yuan-Yu L.

description: The breakfast sandwich is definitely a must have. All of my tastebuds were satisfied. The sandwich is delicately savory with a touch of sweetness from the Hawaiian toast. I also appreciate the coffee ice cubes!
author: Sarin P.

description: Inner Richmond local coffee house... I love it. Friendly service, cool little location, with little tables and chairs out front. And, of course, awesome coffee.
author: Greg S.

description:
Great small neighborhood shop. We went here a few times while we were staying in the Inner Richmond neighborhood. 

Servers was friendly, fast and great. 

Defiantly check it out in there area.
author: Will M.

description: This is the sister cafe to Snowbird in the inner sunset. The owners are friendly and have succeeded in creating some cozy neighborhood spots to support the local community. The Richfield is petite, but comfortable offering a selection of tea, coffee (Snowbird roasted beans!), cookies and savory sandwiches and also chicken wings. This is a nice locals spot to pick up your morning coffee  or catch up with friends before starting your day.
author: Alice H.

description: Wonderful coffee and cute and clean shop. Went every day for a week while visiting SF. Will definitely be back.
author: Bonnie B.

description: Despite having a soft spot for some of SF's larger coffee roasters in Ritual, Four Barrel, and Flywheel, my experience with Snowbird, and now The Ritchfield were both pleasant and even surprising!  In passing through the area, I made a quick stop at The Richfield to pick up some cold brew and couldn't be more surprised with the quality of the coffee! Served with coffee ice cubes, their cold brew was absolutely delicious.  The shop itself is teeny tiny (parking is SUPER challenging in this area), but there seems to be a fair amount of both coffee and food options that are served here!  While their pastries were gone by the afternoon, it looked like their toast options were still available.  Definitely a great little shop to stop by if you're passing through the area!
author: Lisa I.

description: Super cute cafe that took over the little island spot that used to be Ro Cafe! Interior is cute and hipster, and they offer a great variety of coffees, like good pour over, cortado, and cubano. Also sell cookies (with gluten-free options), and there's a menu up at the front with various food options (like avocado toast and sandwiches!) that I think changes weekly? I really enjoy hanging out in this cute space and am glad that there is really good coffee near me now!
author: Grace D.

description: I ordered a cold brew. Out of cold brew.  I ordered an iced coffee.  No dice. I then ordered an iced latte.  I got 16oz of milk with ice.  And one shot of espresso poured in.
author: Jon K.

description:
Cute clean interior, fun concept, and nicely curated list of coffee and food. I tried the raved-about brekkie sandwich and thought it was good, not mind-blowing. I did enjoy the sweet, soft Hawaiian bread which kind of reminds of the sweeter white bread that I grew up with in Korea. It comes with bacon, cheese, and a little egg omelet with some kind of sweet/savory sauce combination.

I didn't try their coffee but I've routinely frequented Snowbird in the Inner Sunset, which I think is good, if a bit sour. I would come back to try it if I were in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't necessarily seek it out.
author: Kate M.

description: A true gem - great coffee, baked goods from Devil's Tooth, what they make there is tasty, and the owners and staff are wonderful people. Wonderful neighborhood spot and worth the drive even if you don't live near by. My favorite coffee drink is The Spaniard and the breakfast sandwich and avocado toast ate delish. Have to stay away from the home made chocolate cookies with sea salt. Too good.
author: Sherbert B.

description:
The Richfield offers toasties, pasties, and snowbird coffee.

seating: a few tables inside and out.

menu: toasties, breakfast?
brew:  snowbird coffee(2.5)
-strong, bold, robust coffee on the edge.
-freshly brewed cuz they were out

drips:
-parking difficult near here.
author: Victor G.

description:
I can't believe how people are raving about this place. Seriously? Kings Hawaiian bread? You mean the bread they sell at Safeway for $5 a pan loaf since I was a kid? My black sesame ricotta toast (could hardly taste black sesame) was sliced to an average bread slice thickness layered with 9 thin strawberry slices. 
My $2.50 brew coffee was served in a cup that was probably no more than 8oz, maybe 6. Tasted like something I could have made with my Mr. Coffee at home. 
From what I could see, the breakfast sandwich also seemed lackluster for its $7. 

Service was slow. Front guy seemed to know most of the people in line and asked how their weekend was which is nice for them but slows service to a snail's pace and makes newcomers (such as myself) feel like I'm on the outside of the incrowd (just sayin). The other girl working there had a less than pleasant attitude. 

I also don't understand menus that have "specials" with arbitrary names but doesn't explain what the drinks are. And not like I'm gonna ask the flat-affect faces behind the counter. 

If you are local and don't do at-home coffee, this might be the hipster place for you. But if you're looking for somewhere to socialize with a nice ambience, good food, and warm customer service, I'd honestly skip this place.
author: Christine Y.

description:
Really underwhelming. At 7 dollars, the avocado toast doesn't hold a candle to what I've had for less money elsewhere in SF. The bread was thin and lacking in flavor, and the toppings (pickles and spices on top of the avocado) were good, but not enough to redeem it. A good avocado toast should be a hearty and flavorful experience, not a meager and mild one.

At a lower price, I'd be more forgiving, but this place just didn't live up to expectations.
author: Mark R.

description: I absolutely love this place! They are always accommodating with my dairy allergy and very friendly! Make the best chai lattes!! :) love this neighborhood gem!
author: Brittany K.

description: Cute little coffee shop - very enjoyable atmosphere and design. Nice espresso bar. Small- so not a place to linger but a few tables for two. Grab and go experience is nice in morning too here.
author: J K.

description:
So glad this little jewel is in the Richmond. The coffee here is always perfect, and their food offerings, while limited, are delicious and unique. They serve a delicious German apple cake and offer several types of specialty toast for breakfast. I'm in love with the cortados (~$3-4), and the latte art is always on point. They also have a diverse selection of non-standard drinks (lattes/capps). I believe their beans are from Snowbird in the Sunset. 

The only caveat is very limited seating inside and out. It's a small, cozy place, but they have everything that makes a great coffee shop: quality coffee/food, standing room, restroom, wifi, pleasant service.
author: Angela L.

description:
Cute little coffee shop in the odd wedge building between Cornwall and California at 5th Ave.

It's a small space, but they got a surprising amount of cafe tables and chairs in there, along with a couple tables outside.

We ordered: a cold brew for me, and an iced mocha for my foo-foo coffee drinker boyfriend. 

Cold brew was A+! They use coffee ice cubes so while it melts it doesn't water down the beverage. Iced mocha was standard, a little too sweet for me but hey, I drink my coffee black 95% of the time.

Will have to come back for more, and to try some of their food offerings!
author: Liz G.

description: Delicious coffee! The shop is pretty small but they've done a good job of creating space. The barista gave me good advice on which beans to buy to keep at home, and the latte I got was delicious and well-made! They were pretty busy when I got there, but there was still plenty of outdoor seating. Would recommend!
author: Rebecca R.

description:
This is the sister shop to Snowbird over in the inner sunset. And they are definitely sisters, not twins. With the same great commitment to quality, but more light, and outdoor seating, the Richfield is sure to become a neighborhood favorite in no time.

We both had cappuccinos, and my husband devoured his Brekkie Sandwich. He said the tangy sauce set it apart, and the substantial, soft, chewy Hawaiian toast was a welcome departure from all the crunchy  that's been popular around town lately.

To no one's surprise, the cappuccinos were perfect temp, perfect flavor profile, with delightful latte art.


Fair Warning: don't come expecting to order a latte with syrup and whip. It ain't that kinda joint.
author: Sonya I.

description:
Such a Sweet Spot!Fabulous Coffee beans of quality as well as there Amazing Teas. This place is small but has Charm,style,layer back .old school coffee house feel with Superior Items that hit the sweet spot to get your day started.
Solid Gold. Yahoo ,so happy to have this inner Richmond jewel.
Thanks Richfield
author: Connie B.

description: Excellent pour over coffee at The Richfield. We also loved the classic bacon egg and cheese sandwich and the avocado toast. Such a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Nora M.

description: I really tried and really wanted to like this place. There are still some things I do like. I started coming on and off since they opened, since I work in the hood, and I always need fresh caffeine and snack options. I think their toasts and food options are tasty, but their beverages are just so so for how much they charge. The last time I was in, they charged me to add avocado to my to go breakfast toast which is standard and expected, but I realized they left the avocado out once I got to work and didn't have time to do anything to fix it at that point. They charge extra to add almond milk to your drink which, in my opinion, is just tacky. If they took an environmental stand against offering almond milk because it takes so much water to produce almonds, and because we were in a drought for years, I would be fine with that. They used to have the best lemon bars from the devil's teeth bakery, but haven't in a real long time, which is disappointing. It's a cute spot with potential to be great, I just hope they get it together bcause I get tired of going to the Blue Danube all the time.
author: Heather U.

description:
This isn't your average sugar bombed coffee place! A lovely little quaint cafe with high quality tea and coffee beverages to satisfy the pickiest coffee and tea lovers. 

Traditional classic choices that remind me of Italy..they even have Affogato! what? Yessss! (I just threw my head back)

Seasonal bites such as the pumpkin toast and other healthy fresh bites to starve off the belly monster. 

Very unique and authentic beverages. Pour over coffees, high end tea combos. The almond milk cafe latte was fantastic with a touch of vanilla. 

Just how I like it!  Nice tables inside where you can sit quietly and a few benches in the front with a dog water bowl :)
Easy parking
author: Cherie F.

description: Cute quaint spot tucked away off of a busy street. Lots of outdoor seating for those who enjoy sitting outside with their coffee. These folks know what they are doing. Great service and coffee is what you'd expect from a quality coffee establishment. I had a cappuccino and it was great. I would return if I am ever back in Inner Richmond area.
author: Jenna M.

description: Great drinks, though the food menu is a little limited. Still, a killer coffee house with a great vibe.
author: Eric O.

description:
I will start by writing that I did not have coffee here only the Brekkie Sandwich.

The Brekkie was good not great.  They used nice ingredients and the toast was soft and buttery.  I think it's a stretch as a $7 sandwich.  $5 yes.  $7 no.  

This is a small corner spot on 5th and California with 2 outside tables that seat 2 each.  It was nice to sit outside this morning.  This is more of a coffee spit than breakfast spot.
author: Dave R.

description:
Love this spot. I, for one, have a thing for establishments with just the right amount of outside seating. Two tables and two benches will do the trick. Check mark for The Richfield. Did not have the pleasure of visiting Snowbird, so I'm coming in with no comparison between the two shops. 

Overall, the cold brew was excellent. I stand by the theory that the basics must be done correctly for me to pursue other more complex items. It is very smooth, while still having some fragrance. A lot of the flavor still remains, with almost a creamy finish. The coffee ice cubes give it that last little kick. Also appreciated is that the ice cubes last throughout the length of cold brew experience. Even with my cup fully empty, there still stood 4 solid cubes. 

I didn't have a chance to try any of the food items, but will make it a point on my next visit. And that is a trip I'm very much looking forward to.
author: Carlo D.

description:
The Brevano was refreshing 
      Have a touch of honey in it
      slightly different and good

Quaint tiny space

Not sure ... they use Snowbird beans
They have some compadre-ship with the snowbird group.

Simple small hidden coffee shop on California between 5th and 6th.
Can seat rough est 8 to 10 inside (estimate)
Some seating outside ... weather permitting
author: S.K. Y.

description:
My espresso drink was tasty and beautiful (with foam art). The barista was friendly, informative and made a darn good coffee. The shop is small and cute. My first and only visit was a good experience. Tip: they have chargers you can use to juice up your phone while you juice up yourself with coffee.

Update: went there the next day for breakfast and coffee. Had the Brekkie Sandwich. Yum. It is a savory egg breakfast sandwich with a slightly sweet (almost syrupy) sauce component. Drank the Brevano. It's delicious, but definitely more for serious coffee drinkers (it's strong). The staff continues to be warm and friendly (maybe that reflects the greater vibe of a very kind and accepting city). I will come back the next time I'm in town.
author: Denise S.

description:
This is definitely a neighborhood spot with very good food and coffee, and a unique Hawaiian influence. Prices are reasonable for the fresh quality of food. 

It was pretty busy from 9-10am, so we were lucky to grab a seat. There were lots of dogs with their owners around and a unruly child, so it's more lively than peaceful.

We had the brekkie sandwich. The house sauce was slightly sweet as was the Hawaiian bread it's on making it unique but still hearty. The black sesame ricotta toast was delicious but very sweet. It certainly acted as breakfast dessert. My friend ordered the avocado toast with a fried egg on top - pretty good. The espresso is strong but not burnt. The drip coffee, sipped by my friend, was just okay, nothing extraordinary. 

I like the environment, the music, the easy demeanor (but good service) from the staff. Overall, happy with my experience. We were relieved to find a place with eggs and great coffee in the area.
author: Kaitlin N.

description: Great latte!  Sadly, when I walked by this evening, discovered that their front door was completely smashed out by someone.  Called the local police department to report it.  Hope they don't have to close up shop til it is repaired....
author: Jane F.

description:
Hello new best friend. The Richfield is my new fave destination for Snowbird Coffee, good eats, and friendly service.

I've dropped by and eaten in three times so far, with great results. The coffee is nice and strong, and it's a generous pour into the to-go cups (which they give you even if you dine in, because they know it's a better pour!). 

But the food. Oh, the food. 

Brekkie sandwich is so boss. Buttered and toasted King's Hawaiian, crisp bacon, melty cheddar cheese, and a perfectly symmetrical omelette with some super secret sauce. Give me all the calories. So delicious and filling, you could (in theory) split it with a friend but let's face it, being uncomfortably full off of that is much preferable.

Also had the ricotta toast which is extremely refreshing and bright. The black sesame gives it such an interesting flavor! 

Haven't tried the other breakfast staples (yogurt and granola, avocado toast), and they're still experimenting with their rotating menu items (pulled pork sandwich, Korean chicken wings), but I will for sure be back on the regular to check out the new eats.

P.S. The staff will remember your name after coming in just twice. Seriously, so friendly and welcoming.
author: Bianca P.

description: Love love love this place. Great coffee offerings, and the Brekkie is killer! I just wish there were a few more tables as it gets pretty busy during the weekend rush.
author: Graham P.

description: The black sesame ricotta toast with strawberries is bomb. It's so good that after moving far out of the neighborhood, I still return on Saturdays to fulfill my craving. It's just that good.
author: Maryclaire M.

description:
My new favorite coffee shop in the Richmond district! I always drive here between classes or before work and get an iced mocha and (probably) a Brekkie Sandwich! This combo always hits the spot for me whenever I'm craving food or just need a pick me up!
I started bringing all my friends here and I can tell they love it too! Great place to study at also and there's always dogs passing by.
author: Amy N.

description: Awesome little spot for coffee, tea, or a snack, but it's kind of easy to miss since it pretty much stands alone in a tiny shop right on California and 5th. It's like a typical hipster coffee shop, but with an Asian twist. I'm not that big on coffee at the moment, but they have a wide selection and my bf loves their lattes. I've tried their original teas, like coconut green tea and lychee black tea. Both were really good. They also have a small brunch menu which includes yogurt parfait, black sesame ricotta toast, avocado toast, and the Brekkie (bacon egg sandwich on Hawaiian bread). Highly recommend the avocado toast and the Brekkie! Both are delicious. I wasn't a big fan of the black sesame toast even though I usually love black sesame (I don't think ricotta goes well with it). Staff is also friendly and there are a few tables inside and outside if you want to dine or drink in.
author: Stephanie G.

description: One of my fav coffee spots in the city, rivaling all the greats.  I always get the "Brevano" which is espresso, cream and honey.  So decadent and so delicious.  Other Yelpers like the iced coffee - while I agree it's a great touch to use coffee ice cubes to minimize diluted taste - I didn't love it. The iced coffee itself was diluted and not super flavorful.  It's hard to find a good cold brew that is smooth, dark roast without a sour aftertaste.  Not sure if I was on an off day.  Anyhow, the 5 stars is for the Espresso based drinks only.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Hip coffee joint in the inner Richmond. Just north of all the Clement Street crowds, this little coffee spot is the perfect place to score a nice pour over or coffee drink. It's tight in there, with just a few indoor seats and a few outdoor tables as well. 

Friendly staff and great coffee! Love it for a little afternoon break. Will be back again soon!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
The Brekkie Sandwich is goooood. I can't call it that tho when I order because, well it's kind of a dumb name and I can't bring myself to call it that, but I just say breakfast sandwich and they know what I mean. It's on Hawaiian sweet bread and has some sort of secret sauce on it that takes regular eggs and bacon to another level. They make a pretty mean latte as well. I walk here and get the sandwich and latte to go. (The sandwich doesn't come with anything else--breakfast potatoes or the like--just FYI.)

The place is pretty hip and SUUUUPER small. Like, don't take your two-kid jogging stroller in there, for everyone's sake ... just don't. There are 3 small 2-person (but really 1-person) tables along one side and the coffee-dressing station on the other. 5 people inside would be crowded. They have 2 tables outside and bench tho, for more leisurely sitting if that's what you're into. The guys that work there are really friendly too. Hit it up if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Nikki D.

description: it was really an accidental find of this little coffee shop. i parked closed to this shop and went for lunch. but we could definitely smell the coffee... so nice!  so when we came back , we decided to have some coffee. 2 regular latte and one decaf. all hand made with love!
author: Andy W.

description: Small, neat little coffee/tea/sandwiches shop with cool wood finish counter tops. The staff were all very nice and helpful. Based on the other reviews, I had to get the Brekkie sandwich (omelette with bacon and cheddar folded over and placed between two slices of Hawaiian King toast). The Brekkie was really good and I think the different part about it would be that the egg is made into an omelette form and then folded over; there's also a special sauce that was pretty good. I also got a latte which was well-made and nicely crafted with a floral design made with the milk. Overall satisfying experience here.
author: Will H.

description:
One of my favorite coffee shops around SF and probably one of the best within Richmond (Also try fifty fifty if you haven't). Espresso quality is on point & the workers there are very friendly and answer all questions I have. The Brekkie sandwich is a must if you haven't tried it. 
Everything I've tried so far has been worth it for sure. Will continue to be a regular here.
author: Josh R.

description:
Probably the best coffee in the neighborhood, and I have tried most of the dishes on their limited menu. All of the dishes are delicious. I do not have bacon on the Brekkie, and it tastes great to me. Avocado toast is amazing. Ricotta toast is a tasty surprise. And the chocolate chip cookies- truly truly dangerous.
Service is very friendly, and it is fast turning to a Local's favorite. Sometimes a "retail slut" hanging out for hours on end, but we can look past that. My only wish is that they would have more "portable" food items for when you're on the go, but this place is a very sweet addition to the neighborhood :)
author: roz A.

description: Nice place for a quick breakfast. Had the brekkie sandwich which was really good and filling. Nice portions of eggs, bacon, and cheese and the bread was perfect for it. Price for breakfast with coffees seemed fair, I would come back for sure.
author: Mike S.

description: Tried this because it's around the corner from my new place. Got an iced mocha and it was so good, strong espresso and good chocolate. I'll be a regular for sure. Made pretty fast as well! And it's in an adorable little building.
author: Kayla P.

description: This is probably my favorite coffee shop in SF I love how cozy it is the decor and the friendly workers. It is on the more expensive side but it's worth it!! I usually order hot chocolate or the cafe au lait :9 please support the business!!!
author: Audrey W.

description: This place is so good! Really outstanding iced chai lattes. The brekkie sandwich was phenomenal- it was a suggestion from one of the baristas. The small shop makes it feel welcoming and homey.
author: Camille S.

description:
The people I've encountered working there are not very friendly. Wasn't even acknowledged (with no one else in line) when I came in, the girl at the counter literally looked up at me, said nothing and continued whatever she was doing. 
I ordered a cold brew with almond milk, paid, but then was given one without. Someone else came in and began to order so I asked someone else in the back. He told me they charged for almond milk. I said "oh, even just to put a little in?" 
"Yea. That's what the charge is for".
Uh ok... Except that first off, I actually mentioned it when I ordered and secondly, most places charge extra for making a whole drink with it, not for allowing you to add an ounce on top...so I could have done without the attitude. 
The 2 stars are only because, at least, the cold brew was good.
author: Therese H.

description:
This place is solid. So happy to have them in the neighborhood!

We always get the Spaniard, it's perfect. And they have a good Matcha Latte. 

Top notch quality and friendly service. The sandwiches look so good, I with they had gluten free options. Maybe one day. :)
author: S...... p.

description: Best coffee in the Richmond! Strong enough but not burnt. Good temperature instead of the roasting hot stuff you get elsewhere. Great texture of milk with pretty latte art. Friendly service.
author: Esther R.

description: Great flavor to The Spaniard! Brekkie Sandwich was solid. Bacon was perfectly crispy and the house sauce added a great complimentary flavor. My wife got the Black Sesame Ricotta Toast. Oh my, flavors popped out of that first bite! Homemade Ricotta was incredible! Definitely would come back!
author: Jay O.

description:
This place's got real potential - great coffee menu which includes pour overs and even the cortado, decent snack/quick breakfast options, super friendly service. Cute little space which might just win all the Richmond folks who usually go to the Village Market, Ashley's, or Nourish Cafe (none of which are actually true coffee shops). Jeff who works behind the counter even gave me a few bike tips. I gotta say, Trouble in the Sunset is still where I'd go for toast but I'll try Richfield's ricotta spread next time. The cappuccino I ordered was delicious.

I had wished for a GOOD coffee shop to open up in this tiny corner for a long while and whoa...it actually happened. Definitely calling this a neighborhood fav starting today. 4 star may change to a 5 after a few more visits...
author: Jackie C.

description: Their lattes are super creamy, workers are really friendly! It's a pretty small coffee shop but has cute outdoor seating
author: Michelle C.

description: The Richfield is finally open and I'm thrilled to announce it's just as good (or better) than coffee visionary Eugene Kim's first shop, Snowbird. Richfield offers the standard espresso drinks done right and more custom coffee concoctions that are unique and well crafted. The standout for Richfield is the awesome food menu they offer with 4 items that will satisfy anyone's appetite including a Breakfast 'Brekkie' Sandwich, pulled pork sandwich, and Chong Li chicken wings named after the Korean villain from the 1988 Van Damme film Bloodsport. Everything fits perfectly into the vintage boxing theme of Richfield even the cooler in the back with Rocky and Ivan Drago on it! This neighborhood has needed a great coffee shop for so long and I look forward to returning and seeing the line out the door!
author: Matt F.

description: Look no further if you are in search of the PERFECT cappuccino (or flat white). Best I've had in SF. Smooth and well balanced flavor. Wonderful consistency. (I'm not a fan of "third wave" bright/fruity/citrusy, light/medium roast that you find all over SF these days; it tastes like sour coffee to me.).
author: Ruth C.

description: Great spot to get a latte and sit outside on a nice day.
author: Amin S.

description:
This spot instantly became my go-to for morning coffee and reading. While the interior is small, I've never had trouble finding a place to sit and enjoy my cold brew (with coffee ice cubes) and brekkie sandwich. I can't attest to the weekend crowd as I've only gone on weekdays, but I can only imagine that the line would be out the door. 

The Richfield is the perfect neighborhood coffee shop with friendly baristas and simple yet satisfying food and beverage menus. This place is everything I want and need in a local coffee shop.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Stellar new addition to the Inner Richmond neighborhood. Located on a little sidewalk island at 5th and California St. -  a few blocks from Mountain Lake Park (in the Presidio) and 1 block from the main shopping/restaurant drag on Clement St.

They make excellent espresso drinks. Has the perfect balance of boldness and smooth finish for me. Not over-roasted at all, but also not a super light (bright) roast either. They seem to rotate coffees from Snowbird, which are good quality. Their drip coffee is also good quality - good enough to enjoy black.

Service is friendly. There are 3 small tables inside, a standing area with a counter height rail, and 2 small tables on the sidewalk with a few benches (and a dog water bowl). Good place to hang out with your dog outside.

Brekkie Sandwich is very good. Big Hawaiian toast with a healthy amount of eggs, thick cut bacon, cheddar, and a unique sweet sauce (you can request it without sauce if you're not feeling adventurous). Haven't had anything else on the menu because the Brekkie sandwich keeps getting the job done for me. There are about 4-5 other menu items, including a cinnamon sugar toast, which looked pretty damn good.
author: Paul L.

description: This is one of my favourite coffee spots in the city currently. Great coffee and tasty food options. It's a cozy friendly spot with not a whole lot of seating but I have never found that to be a problem. My go to spot in the inner Richmond!
author: Alasdair S.

description: Best breakfast sandwich I've had. And $7? Perfect. It's so cozy and homey, the guy working seems to know everyone and is so friendly! Thanks so much for great food, service, and vibes!
author: Lauren H.

description: My favorite coffee place in the Inner Richmond. Friendly neighborhood vibe with great coffee and delicious food and baked items. A latte along with the Brekkie sandwich or a yogurt parfait is usually my go-to but you really can't go wrong here.
author: Kelly L.

description: Nice selection of vintage RIng magazines.  $2.50 for brew coffee is a bit steep amigos.  Kinda 'precious' for my taste (the Kurdish/Turkish cafe had more soul/authenticity, not so much of a wanna-be 'hipster' vibe) but we SF natives must adapt to the changes and screen people...
author: Michael G.

description:
Wonderful atmosphere, food looked delish. 

Beware: only whole milk or almond available, and no sweeteners except sugar. 

A little too purist/snobby for my taste, but the coffee is good
author: Roberta G.

description: The coffee is excellent, and I'm looking forward to trying the food because it looks great. However, I do NOT understand why they're charging $2.50 for a double shot of espresso and $3.50 for an Americano, which is a double shot cut with water. Even in a hundred-year drought, charging an entire extra buck for a little water seems excessive.
author: Fawn F.

description: Yummm I love the Richfield. I ordered the chai tea latte and the black sesame ricotta toast, which were both amazing. This was the first time in awhile where I encountered a chai tea latte that wasn't overwhelming sweet- This place made it just perfectly! The interior is small but cozy and there are plenty of specialty coffee drinks to try. I definitely recommend coming here!
author: Kat L.

description: Wonderful pour over coffee. Great service. I'm so happy this little spot is in my hood!
author: Brooke S.

description: Love love love this little coffee shop. My go to when I'm in my boyfriends neighborhood . The coffee is yummy and the avocado toast is a must try! Sooo bomb. The staff is very friendly . I just love this place.
author: Lizzy H.

description: Really delicious coffee. The brekkie sandwich is also awesome, though you'll crash from the sandwich equivalent of a sugar high 30 min after eating it. One star off because the hot chocolate consistently tastes more like sweet milk than chocolate. Glad this place opened up.
author: Rose G.

description: I really love this place! It's truly a gem of Inner Richmond, and I've had some of the best flat whites in the city here. The staff are also super nice.
author: Stephen H.

description: Go there for the coffee and stay for the Sandwiches. The Pork sandwich is amazing. The pork, properly slow cooked with so many delicious goodness that it will leave you wondering what the hell just happened in you mouth! Do you notice why there are no pictures of the delicious Pork Sandwich? You can't take a freaking photo cause the moment it comes out, the phone goes away and the eating begins. It taste like a Pernil with some caribbean influenced and their own creativity. Officially hooked and so close to home!
author: Tavo P.

description: Best addition to Inner Richmond. Ask my friends - I love coffee and I don't mess around with my coffee. This place has so much heart and the ppl are so friendly. Reasons why I keep coming back.
author: K C.

description: Delicious coffee, and great service! Free wifi, and outdoor seating as well. Wish they were open later than 3.
author: Saniya C.

description: Good coffee in a location that has seen a lot of turnover, but has great potential for the right vibe. Heard that their sister shop in the Sunset is the jam, so all signs are promising. Tried a pour over yesterday, will try the food this weekend!
author: Mark C.

description: Neat new coffee spot. Replaced another that was okay. Must be limited walking traffic. Check it out and keep local businesses local and thriving.  Good coffee and outside seating for a a couple of couples. Great stop on the way to Sunday Clement farmers market.
author: Why N.

description: hip coffee personified. quirky food. cool vibe
author: roger m.

description:
Best coffee, so great. Raw sugar syrup, almond milk, nice & warm.

Brekkie sandwich is made with Kings Hawaiian bread, WINNNN
author: Tania C.

description: This is a tiny and neat coffee shop with few seating spaces. I got a cold brew which was really refreshing and delicious. The ice cubes were two big blocks, keeping the coffee nice and cold for a while. Aside from the coffee, service was awesome as well.
author: Pui L.

description: Breakfast sandwich and Cafecito great way to start my morning before the commute to downtown. Also for the lunch time grab the Korean chicken wings is a must have.
author: Sammy F.

description: Excellent coffee, my husband came back twice the same day for it, sooo sooo good! We tried the toast with ricotta cheese with honey, tasted great, perfect for breakfast. My husband got a sandwich with bacon and eggs, was delicious too. Good atmosphere, sports bar vibe, cool little spot. Definitely will come back.
author: Anastasia K.

description: Great pour-over, solid food. Perfectly located for a coffee before or after a bike ride across the golden gate bridge.
author: Chris M.

description: This place is the size of a postage stamp, but they make a great cappuccino.  I'd stay from the beer/bacon muffins, but i'll be back soon
author: Dennis M.

description: $2.50 for a double shot of espresso vs $3.50 for an Americano made with a double shot is crazy.  And then to be told by the barista "that's normal" was even worse.  A double shot Americano at Ashley's across the street is $2.01 (and it's organic and free trade).  Seems like a fine place, but they need an attitude adjustment to the Richmond...
author: Ryan H.

description: I was going to give them more stars, but the lack of soymilk is a real issue for my family. Without it, I can't bring the kids.
author: Imershein L.

description: Visited San Francisco 3 weeks ago from San Diego and found this place on Yelp. Good location, Very nice employees, good coffee, and great food. The Brekkie Sandwich with Avocado was the best! Definetly coming back next time we visit.
author: Paul B.

description: Amazing coffee, amazing staff, the toasts are delicious, and the space is super cute. My favorite neighborhood cafè!
author: Nica M.

description: Best coffee in SF. Try the cortado or flat white with a brekkie sandwich and you won't regret it!!!
author: Sarah S.
